Message.Msg: Bluetooth capability? Intel CentrinoÂ® Advanced-N 6235 802.11n Half Size Mini PCIe Bluetooth 4.0 Combo Adapter 6235ANHMW 802.11 a/b/g/n 300 Mbps $21.99 from Amazon. Wireless and bluetooth. Review: I got this for my Intel NUC that I built. The Bluetooth got detected on windows 7 but the WiFi needed a driver download. Once you have them, this product works like a charm. I gave it 5 stars because I've tried other Bluetooth dongles to no avail. I had used an ASUS USB Bluetooth which wouldn't find my Bluetooth remote, then I tried a Belkin which worked fine until I rebooted. This one keep the connection stable. I'm glad I went with this. Go for it. Hope this helps someone make their decision.

Message.Title: Two dishonest players.
Message.Msg: Look at the tell signs on both the NASDAQ/NYSE. What is happening is stagnation in the major indices. This happens when the large derivative players are shifting their positions. They are now moving money and are going to bet against both markets. In the past this is when large corrections take place (over 10 percent). The large derivative players are the ones that run the indices. For example look at Warren Buffet; he is a heavy derivative player that has, over the last five years, substantially decreased his position in stocks and gone the derivative route. Topic.Title: What is so revolutionary about intel TV?

Message.Msg: It's easier to begin with what won't change with Intel's Web TV. First, Intel would be delivering the same bundled video content MSO's already deliver to consumers so that won't change, except Intel's bundles might be bundled slightly differently. Intel's Web TV is expected to be priced roughly equal to what MSO's charge so that won't change either. Intel plans to also deliver video content to tablets and smartphones but MSO's are already doing that too. What will change is that the consumer's live TV viewing experience will be dependent on the stability of their Internet connection which often slows to a crawl even for premium cable broadband services. So Intel customers may have to rely on the cloud to watch recorded live programming they missed when their Internet connection couldn't keep up. Also while they watch live TV they'll also be using a significant portion of their monthly data allocation built in to their fixed-price broadband service, so they may want to buy another Internet service to use for their PCs. The customer also won't have single billing for broadband & TV service because they'll be paying separately for the OTTP TV service. Since they won't be buying their HDTV service and Internet together from their MSO, they may have lose whatever discounts they had for buying both packages together. Now what was novel? The most creative idea was the concept of the embedded camera to generate a new revenue source monetizing consumer's privacy with facial recognition technology and selling that data off to who knows who under the pretense of "improving the consumer experience". While creative, it is a bad idea nonetheless that should have never gone forward, and in the current climate is unlikely to produce the hoped-for revenue to redefine the TV industry business model or convince content producers to unbundle their content.

Topic.Title: TSMC and Apple

Message.Msg: "Apple has recently signed a foundry partnership agreement with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), industry sources have claimed. Under the terms of the agreement, TSMC will apply its 28nm and 20nm process technologies to produce Appleâs next-generation CPUs, according to the sources." That was dated September 2011 and It's half true and half false 1.) My guestimate was that Apple decision to go with TSMC at 20 nm was made about 2 years. It certainly was not decided yesterday or last week or last month although DT creates the perception it was recently signed. Equipment vendor ASML was very vocal TSMC building up 20 nm capacity and there should be no surprise - what's coming beyond 20nm is not decided. Common sense says that Apple (or any other customer that never worked with TSMC) would wait to see how 20nm goes before making commitments about 16nm - to mention 10 nm, 10 nm is, rediculous 2.) Apple could NOT switch to TSMC at 28nm because 32nm Samsung process is based on gate first while TSMC is gate last. (so Apple going at 28nm with TSMC was pure BS but shows how little they understand - it's a stupid statement) 3.) ALTR explicitly explained that one of the reasons why turning to Intel is that TSMC FinFet is based on 20nm design rules - IOW going from 20nm to 16nm FinFet will not or only result in a very little die shrink 4.) 3 years is probably the lifetime for 20nm beginning with risk production, ramp up and maturity

Message.Title: INTC Likelihood of Fabbing Apple Chips Rises, Says Lazard
Message.Msg: Lazard Capital semiconductor analyst Daniel Amir today reiterated a Buy rating on shares of Intel (INTC), writing that the chances of the company becoming a contract chip maker for Apple (AAPL) are more likely than they have in past. Based on our recent checks across the supply channel, we highlight the impact and reasons why a widely anticipated deal with Apple as a potential foundry customer is becoming more likely,â writes Amir. Among the factors Amir includes are newly installed CEO Brian Krzanich being more open to the prospect of Apple as a foundry customer; having the technology edge in manufacturing over contract foundry Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM); having some excess capacity in new factories that will be rolling out in the next two years; and having already dedicated resources to contract work for other large customers. Apple is Samsung Electronicsâs (005930KS) biggest customer for contract chip manufacture, which manufactures the A-series chips that Apple designs and puts in its iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch. Those parts rely on designs from ARM Holdings (ARMH), not Intelâs traditional âX86â microprocessor instruction set, which has made the prospect of Intel contracting to Apple a controversial one for Intel. But Intel can improve EPS if it lures away some of that Samsung business, writes Amir: With Apple being one of the largest consumers of foundry capacity, we analyze the impact if Intel were to secure Apple as a customer. Currently, Apple uses Samsung as its fab, where it accounts for ~90% of Samsungâs foundry revenue, or ~$3.85B in FY12. Based on our assumptions for iPhone and iPad units (expected to grow ~20% Y/Y), we believe the potential revenue impact for Intel could be $2.97B in with an incremental $0.14 of EPS in 2015E (assuming 50% of Appleâs business). On Krzanich, who took over from Paul Otellini last month, he âwas previously the companyâs COO and has extensive manufacturing and technology expertise,â notes Amir. âKrzan

Topic.Title: TSMC and Apple

Message.Msg: A rumor published by DigiTimes claims that the A8 chip designed for 2014â²s iDevices will be manufactured mostly by TSMC (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company). TSMC and its partner Global UniChip will be supplying A-series processors based on 20nm, 16nm and 10nm process nodes. Trial runs for production of the chips will allegedly begin in the next few weeks, and full production will kick off in early 2014. Apparently, as part of the deal, 3 entire facilities in southern Taiwan will be reserved exclusively for the production of Appleâs processors. DigiTimes over the past few years has had something of a patchy track record. Granted, the company did well last year with iPad rumors. However, rumors of the iPhone 5 arriving in 2011 were way off, and since then the company hasnât had the best reputation for gaining reliable information. As noted by AppAdvice, itâs also been quoted this year as saying Intel and TSMC will be producing chips for this yearâs devices. That has yet to be confirmed or heard by anyone else, anywhere. Who makes the chips really isnât the biggest issue in the world. Itâs more that Apple is allegedly weening itself off Samsungâs parts and finding other suppliers who can provide the same quantity and quality of parts for its products. TSMC is a familiar name, and is regarded as being an industry expert in chip-making. As is always the case with part rumors, we wonât find out if theyâre true until the devices are launched and taken apart. From todaysiphone

Topic.Title: TSMC and Apple

Message.Msg: Of course I have to look at things differently. The 20nm is a cover story, Apple knows it's not going to happen the way that TSMC claims it will. There are parts of the story we'll only find out years from now. Though this could be Apple's payback to Intel for some perceived sins, I doubt it. I think that Apple has bought into the concept of designer processors. They have a staff of over 1000 working on their A Processor line. Tim Cook has in the past made moves that are path of least resistant, least amount of change. Messing with the A processor means messing with the formula of the iProducts. What they have with TSMC is an agreement where this FAB is swearing to put out their best products first.to Apple. It also keeps ARM viable in a period where Intel enters the smartphone market. I don't think Apple is going to run for cover when they find out that 20nm will be delayed. They still don't feel hardware is that important to their success. During the Steve Jobs era Apple kept putting out fake benchmarks about how much faster their RISC processors were compared to Intel. Some people bought into it. The next few years are going to be learning years for Apple. They are going to be paying premium rates for low yields of nearly vaporware processors. They are gong to watch their loyal customers eventually lose faith and move to new phone platforms though Apple currently feels that they will stick with them through thick and thin. Blackberry wasn't a large enough warning for Apple. They are destined to head down same road.

Message.Title: Apple's Hail Mary Pass
Message.Msg: Despite what everybody else here may suggest I don't think Apple is stupid. They are desperate, which kinda looks similar. They really feel that they've found the cure for cancer with their little A processor line. By pumping a hell of a lot of money into TSMC and being the largest and most important customer TSMC can keep the A series relevant for three more years. The alternative is to get on board with Intel, perhaps lay off 1000 or more people associated with their processor development division at a time when the stock is suffering. Yes the 20nm production is pure fantasy. They will most likely announce 28nm based iPhone 6 in September. This will be out at a time when Intel will have 14nm out on the street hitting them left and right. Perhaps by end of next year 20nm will be announced. That is, if Apple is willing to pay for a lot of R&D and low yield lots. You really hope that Apple knows what it's doing, but they are backing the wrong horse for a few years. For a technology company they are very resistant to change.

Topic.Title: Apple's Hail Mary Pass

Message.Msg: 20 nm planar is already very expensive compared to 28nm (ASML figures 1.7x). Than moving on to 16nm (TSMC) / 14 nm (Glofo/Samsung) FinFet adds additonal cost in regards to equipment BUT it also adds cost for redesigning (from planar to 3D) AND there is almost NO cost advantage because ARM FinFet is based on 20nm design rules. On the other hand Intel will deliver a true 14nm SoC and there should be a nice cost benefit when moving from 22nm SoC to 14nm SoC. ARM's power/performance advantage relative to Intel is finally being questioned. The next "thing" that will "sink in" is that ARM foundries will be faced with record capex and incapability to shrink FinFet die to offset increasing cost. Supposedly TSMC will not have a shrink until 10nm will be based on 14nm design rules...10nm is really (based on Moore's law) 14nm and 16nm is really 20nm

Topic.Title: Apple's Hail Mary Pass

Message.Msg: "According to DigiTimes, TSMC will start to manufacture Apple's A8 chips in small volume as soon as next month, and substantially ramp up its 20nm production capacity after December." [Hmmmm. Is 2015 after December?] A copy of the production schedule looked like this: December: Make 4 or at least something that vaguely looks like a chip that we can show the press. Jan, Feb, Mar: Make 16 so we can say our ramp is beyond expectations. Apr, May, June: Check with engineering and see when the first samples will actually arrive. Tell the press everything is on schedule. July, Aug, Sep: Tell the press we are beginning volume production and call engineering again to get the real story. Oct, Nov, Dec: Make 32 and check with engineering to see what kind of problems we are really having. Tell press that all parties are happy with the ramp. You can't make this stuff up but TSMC can...

Message.Msg: I can tell you one of his statements was completely inaccurate today. The part where he says: However, âGiven atrocious PC results in Q1 (down ~14% YoY, the worst quarter since data collection began), it seems unlikely that this kind of growth could be driven by PCs.â But these were Intel's actual results as can be seen at Intel's website regarding their earnings call. Last year's PC data group revenue for Intel's Q1 was $8.499 Billion. This year's Q1 results were at $7.992 Billion. That is an actual drop of about 6%. Not the 14% Ragson is trying to get readers to believe. It's strange how Barron's does not check his statements for accuracy.

Message.Title: Lenovo Miix Tablet, New S and U Series Units This Summer
Message.Msg: [So many new Intel products...] Lenovo has introduced a new tablet, three notebooks and two Ultrabooks. Last week Lenovo introduced a number of new products including a 10.1 inch tablet called the Miix. The launch saw a total of six devices in all spanning tablets to touch-based notebooks to Ultrabooks starting at $429 this summer. For starters, the 10.1 inch Windows 8-based Miix tablet will sport a dual-core Intel Atom SoC and a "quick-flip" detachable folio case with an integrated AccuTyper keyboard, allowing the user to instantly switch between PC mode and tablet mode. Other features will include an IPS display sporting a 1366 x 768 resolution, up to 64 GB of internal storage, an SD card slot for 32 GB of extra storage, and a battery that boasts up to 10 hours of battery life. Lenovo said the tablet will be extremely light, weighing a mere 1.2 pounds and measure just 0.4 inches thin. It will also include integrated Bluetooth 4.0, Wi-Fi connectivity (likely Wireless N) and optional 3G-GPS connectivity. Unfortunately, the company didn't provide additional specs, but the device is due this summer with a starting price of approximately $500. Next up is Lenovo's S Series laptops which will be injected with three new touch-based solutions, the S400 Touch, S500 Touch and S210 Touch, costing approximately $449, $579 and $429 respectively later this summer. The IdeaPad S400 and S500 can be configured with up to third-generation Intel Core i5 processors and optional discrete graphics. The IdeaPad S210 will be equipped with up to third generation Intel Core i3 processors. Nope, no Haswell here. From Tom's Hardware

Topic.Title: Lenovo Miix Tablet, New S and U Series Units This Summer

Message.Msg: Cont'd: All three devices will also offer Dolby Advance Audio v2 certification as well as Lenovo Companion, Lenovo Support, Lenovo Cloud and OneKey Recovery applications, the last of which will make data backup and recovery rather simple. The S400 and S500 will come with 14-inch and 15.6-inch HD widescreen displays respectively while the S210 will sport an 11.6-inch HD widescreen display. All three will have a tactile metallic finish and a thin and light frame. Finally there's the IdeaPad U series Ultrabooks which now includes the U330 Touch and U430 Touch. Starting from only 0.77 inches thin, Lenovo said they can be as thin as a smartphone, but offer up advanced features like motion control, voice control, a multi-touch touchpad and a 10-point capacitive multi-touch screen. So touchy. The new Ultrabooks can be configured with up to a fourth-generation Intel Core i7 "Haswell" processor plus optional Nvidia GeForce graphics. They can also be configured with storage up to 1 TB HDD with 16 GB SSD or 500 GB SSHD with integrated 16 GB NAND flash or 256 GB SSD storage. The U330 Touch will come with a 13.3-inch HD or FHD display and the U430 Touch with a 14-inch HD+ or FHD display. Slated to launch this summer, the IdeaPad U330 will cost approximately $799 and the IdeaPad U430 will cost approximately $899. Both will be packed into a metal frame that still stays light at as little as 3.7 pounds, Lenovo said. From Tom's Hardware
